mechanism_of_action.References: Poryadin GV et al; Byull Eksp Biol Med 84 (9): 341-3 (1977)
mechanism_of_action.Value: Potassium arsenite (200 mug/ml) completely blocked the anaphylactic contractions of isolated human intestinal strips and anaphylactic bronchospasm in guinea pigs. It also inhibited anaphylactic release of biologically active cmpd during perfusion of guinea pig lung.

non_human_toxicity_excerpts.References: WHO; Environmental Health Criteria Document No. 18: Arsenic. Available from, as of July 6, 2009: https://www.inchem.org/pages/ehc.html
non_human_toxicity_excerpts.Value: /LABORATORY ANIMALS: Subchronic or Prechronic Exposure/ 14 /Swiss/ mice /were painted/ with a total of 30 mg of potassium arsenite (8.7 mg As), dissolved in methanol, once a week for 10 weeks. Croton oil was also applied weekly, starting 25 days later. Three papillomas were observed in mice treated with potassium arsenite, while 4 papillomas appeared in 19 animals receiving croton oil only.

non_human_toxicity_excerpts.References: IARC. Monographs on the Evaluation of the Carcinogenic Risk  of Chemicals to Humans. Geneva: World Health Organization,  International Agency for Research on Cancer, 1972-PRESENT.  (Multivolume work). Available at: https://monographs.iarc.fr/ENG/Classification/index.php, p. V23 86 (1980)
non_human_toxicity_excerpts.Value: /LABORATORY ANIMALS: Chronic Exposure or Carcinogenicity/ A group of 100 mice were painted 3 times weekly with soln of potassium arsenite in ethanol containing 1.8% arsenic trioxide, later reduced to 0.12% due a to high death rate. Of 33 mice that lived for 3 months, 1 developed a metastasizing squamous-cell carcinoma of the skin after 5.5 months.

non_human_toxicity_excerpts.References: IARC. Monographs on the Evaluation of the Carcinogenic Risk  of Chemicals to Humans. Geneva: World Health Organization,  International Agency for Research on Cancer, 1972-PRESENT.  (Multivolume work). Available at: https://monographs.iarc.fr/ENG/Classification/index.php, p. V2 59 (1973)
non_human_toxicity_excerpts.Value: /LABORATORY ANIMALS: Chronic Exposure or Carcinogenicity/ Negative results were ... obtained ... on cocarcinogenicity to mouse skin ... /by/ oral admin over 5 days of a total of 2.4 mg potassium arsenite/mouse to 20 Rockland all-purpose mice, 2-wk feeding of 0.676 g/kg of diet to 30 skin-tumor-susceptible mice or 48-wk of 0.169 g potassium arsenite/kg of diet (0.338 mg/kg of diet in first week only) to 30 skin-tumor-susceptible mice. These ... treatments were coupled with skin painting with croton oil or DMBA plus croton oil.

non_human_toxicity_excerpts.References: IARC. Monographs on the Evaluation of the Carcinogenic Risk  of Chemicals to Humans. Geneva: World Health Organization,  International Agency for Research on Cancer, 1972-PRESENT.  (Multivolume work). Available at: https://monographs.iarc.fr/ENG/Classification/index.php, p. V23 83 (1980)
non_human_toxicity_excerpts.Value: /LABORATORY ANIMALS: Chronic Exposure or Carcinogenicity/ ... Oral admin of 1 drop of ... Fowler's soln/wk for 5 months to ... 30 mice ... total dose of 7 mg ... led to significant incr in number of tumor-bearing animals. Tumors included adenocarcinomas of skin, lung, & lymph nodes & were observed at 14 months. ... No tumors were seen in 15 control mice. ... Tumors were observed in offspring of treated mothers, /after oral administration of Fowler's soln/ but not in offspring of control mice ...

/LABORATORY ANIMALS: Developmental or Reproductive Toxicity/ Potassium arsenite, approx LD50 = 0.004 mg/egg, was introduced via yolk sac injection in 4-day old white leghorn chick embryo. The agent was dissolved in physiological saline. No effect on growth or development.

/LABORATORY ANIMALS: Developmental or Reproductive Toxicity/ Potassium arsenite in water was injected into chick embryos: LD50 for 4-day chick embryo 0.02 mg/egg (0.10 microatoms/egg); LD50 for 8-day embryo was 0.34 microatoms/egg; LD50 for 8-day embryo via chorioallantoic membrane was 0.07 microatoms/egg. There was no evidence of malformations.

non_human_toxicity_excerpts.References: Tinwell H et al; Env Health Perspect 95: 205-10 (1991). Available from, as of June 24, 2009: https://www.pubmedcentral.nih.gov/articlerender.fcgi?artid=1568403
non_human_toxicity_excerpts.Value: /GENOTOXICITY/ Sodium arsenite, potassium arsenite, and Fowler's solution (arsenic trioxide dissolved in potassium bicarbonate) are equally active in the mouse bone marrow micronucleus assay (approximately 10 mg/kg by IP injection). The natural ore orpiment (principally As2S3) was inactive despite blood levels of arsenic of 300 to 900 ng/mL in treated mice at 24 hr. Sodium arsenite was active in three strains of mice. It is suggested that the human lung cancer observed among arsenic ore smelters and the skin cancer among people exposed therapeutically to Fowler's solution, have, as their common origin, the genotoxic arsenite ion AsO2-...

non_human_toxicity_excerpts.References: IARC. Monographs on the Evaluation of the Carcinogenic Risk  of Chemicals to Humans. Geneva: World Health Organization,  International Agency for Research on Cancer, 1972-PRESENT.  (Multivolume work). Available at: https://monographs.iarc.fr/ENG/Classification/index.php, p. V84 (2004)
non_human_toxicity_excerpts.Value: /GENOTOXICITY/ Potassium arsenite tested in C57BL mice was also positive in the micronucleus test in polychromatic erythrocytes.

non_human_toxicity_excerpts.References: Poryadin GV et al; Byull Eksp Biol Med 84 (9): 341-3 (1977)
non_human_toxicity_excerpts.Value: /ALTERNATIVE and IN VITRO TESTS/ Potassium arsenite (200 ug/mL) completely blocked ... anaphylactic bronchospasm in guinea pigs. It also inhibited anaphylactic release of biologically active cmpd during perfusion of guinea pig lung.
